Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Respondents knowingly sold infringing computers despite awareness of injunctions; evidence included rebranding and misleading sales practices
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the plaintiff to prove willful violation
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Respondents acted deliberately and with knowledge through legal counsel
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Contempt occurs when a party knowingly violates a court order
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Compliance with show cause order under Rule 355
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Continued sale of infringing products post-injunction
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Hearing conducted with opportunity to respond
Crimes.Court_Result: Fines imposed; suspended sentences with compliance conditions
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Failed to comply with injunctions despite knowledge
Crimes.Authority: Court with jurisdiction over IP enforcement

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Unauthorized use of copyrighted material in computers
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Respondents sold computers incorporating Apple’s copyrighted designs despite court orders
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the plaintiff to prove ownership and infringement
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Respondents had legal representation and were aware of injunctions
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Copyright protection extends to original works used in commercial products
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Sale of computers using Apple’s protected software and design elements
Crimes.Review_Standard: Correctness for legal issues, reasonableness for factual findings
Crimes.Applicant_Challenge: Preventing ongoing unauthorized use of intellectual property
Crimes.Defendant_Response: No valid defense presented; continued sales observed

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Use of confusingly similar symbols to Apple’s registered trademark
Crimes.Governing_Law: Trade Marks Act, R.S.C. 1970, c. T-10
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Symbols on keyboards resembled Apple’s logo and could mislead consumers
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On plaintiff to prove likelihood of confusion
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: First impression test applied; visual similarity noted
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Trademark infringement occurs when use causes likely confusion
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: First impression test for consumer confusion
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Violation of injunction prohibiting use of similar marks
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Use of apple-like logos on computers after injunction
Crimes.Applicant_Challenge: Protection against brand dilution and consumer confusion
Crimes.Legal_Rule_Source: Trade Marks Act, R.S.C. 1970, c. T-10
Crimes.Defendant_Response: No justification for symbol use provided
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Trade Marks Act, R.S.C. 1970, c. T-10
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Cited: Trade Marks Act, R.S.C. 1970, c. T-10
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Likelihood of confusion with registered mark
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Trade Marks Act, R.S.C. 1970, c. T-10
